description: A categorized list of common musical instruments found across various genres and cultures.

families.name: String Instruments
families.description: Produce sound from vibrating strings. The vibration is set in motion by plucking, bowing, or striking the strings.

families.name: Wind Instruments
families.description: Produce sound from vibrating air, typically by blowing into a mouthpiece.

subfamilies.name: Woodwinds
subfamilies.description: Instruments that were originally made of wood. Sound is produced by blowing across an edge or through a reed.

subfamilies.name: Brass
subfamilies.description: Instruments where the sound is produced by sympathetic vibration of air in a tubular resonator in sympathy with the vibration of the player's lips.

families.name: Percussion Instruments
families.description: Produce sound by being struck, scraped, or shaken.

subfamilies.name: Pitched Percussion
subfamilies.description: Produce notes with an identifiable pitch.

subfamilies.name: Unpitched Percussion
subfamilies.description: Produce sounds with an indefinite pitch, used to provide rhythm.

families.name: Electronic Instruments
families.description: Produce sound using electronics. An electric current is used to generate an audio signal.

instruments.name: Synthesizer
instruments.description: Generates audio signals through methods such as subtractive synthesis, additive synthesis, and frequency modulation synthesis.

instruments.name: Drum Machine
instruments.description: An electronic instrument that creates percussion sounds, drum beats, and patterns. (e.g., Roland TR-808, TR-909).

instruments.name: Sampler
instruments.description: An electronic or digital musical instrument which uses sound recordings (or 'samples') of real instrument sounds, excerpts from recorded songs or found sounds.

instruments.name: Theremin
instruments.description: An early electronic instrument controlled without physical contact by the thereminist.

instruments.name: MIDI Keyboard
instruments.description: A piano-style keyboard used for sending MIDI signals to other devices. It does not produce sound on its own.
